factoid: Rostóv was pondering about winning back six hundred rubles, an ace, a corner, and a nine, and said winning it back is impossible.
Rostóv wondered why someone was doing this to Rostóv.
Sometimes Rostóv staked a large sum.
Dólokhov refused to accept Rostóv's stake and set the stake himself.
Nicholas submitted to Dólokhov.
Nicholas prayed to God as Nicholas had done on the battlefield at the bridge over the Enns.
Nicholas guessed that the first card dealt from the crumpled heap under the table would save Nicholas.
Nicholas counted the cords on Nicholas's coat and took a card with that number.
Nicholas tried staking the total of Nicholas's losses on that card.
Nicholas looked around for aid from other players.
Nicholas peered at the now cold face of Dólokhov and tried to read what was passing in Dólokhov's mind.
Rostóv thought that Dólokhov knows what the loss means to Rostóv.
Rostóv thought that Dólokhov cannot want Rostóv's ruin.
Rostóv thought that Dólokhov was Rostóv's friend.
Rostóv thought that Rostóv was fond of Dólokhov.
Rostóv thought that it is not Dólokhov's fault.
Rostóv thought that it is not Rostóv's own fault either.
Rostóv thought that he had done nothing wrong.
Rostóv wondered if he had killed anyone, insulted anyone, or wished harm to anyone.
Rostóv wondered why there was such a terrible misfortune.
Rostóv wondered when the misfortune began.
Rostóv had come to the table a little while ago with the thought of winning a hundred rubles to buy a casket for Mamma's name day.
Rostóv planned to go home after winning a hundred rubles.
Rostóv felt happy, free, and lighthearted at that time.
Rostóv did not realize how happy Rostóv was.
Rostóv wondered when that happiness ended and when the new terrible state began.
Rostóv wondered what marked the change.
Rostóv sat all the time in the same place at the table.
Rostóv chose and placed cards.
Rostóv watched broad-boned agile hands in the same way.
Rostóv wondered when the change happened and what had happened.
Rostóv said he was well, strong, and still the same and in the same place.
Rostóv said it cannot be.
Rostóv said it will all end in nothing.
Rostóv was flushed and bathed in perspiration.
The room was not hot.
Rostóv's face was terrible and piteous to see.
Rostóv's face was especially from its helpless efforts to seem calm.
The score against Rostóv reached the fateful sum of forty-three thousand.
Rostóv had just prepared a card by bending the corner of which he meant to double the three thousand just put down to Rostóv's score.
Dólokhov slammed down the pack of cards.
Dólokhov put the card aside.
Dólokhov began rapidly adding up the total of Rostóv’s debt.
Dólokhov broke the chalk as he marked the figures in his clear, bold hand.
Some swarthy men and women entered from the cold outside and spoke in gypsy accents.
Nicholas understood that it was all over.
Nicholas said in an indifferent tone: "Well, won’t you go on? I had a splendid card all ready."
Nicholas thought "It’s all up! I’m lost!"
Nicholas thought "Now a bullet through my brain—that’s all that’s left me!"
Nicholas said in a cheerful voice: "Come now, just this one more little card!"
Dólokhov said "All right!" after finishing addition.
Dólokhov said "All right! Twenty-one rubles," pointing to figure twenty-one by which the total exceeded the round sum of forty-three thousand.
Dólokhov prepared to deal a pack.
Rostóv submissively unbent the corner of his card and instead of the six thousand he had intended, carefully wrote twenty-one.
Rostóv said "It’s all the same to me."
Rostóv said "I only want to see whether you will let me win this ten, or beat it."
Dólokhov began to deal seriously.
Rostóv detested at that moment those hands with short reddish fingers and hairy wrists.
The ten fell to Rostóv.
Dólokhov said "You owe forty-three thousand, Count."
Dólokhov added "One does get tired sitting so long."
Rostóv said "Yes, I’m tired too."
Dólokhov cut Rostóv short, as if to remind Rostóv that it was not for Rostóv to jest.
Dólokhov asked "When am I to receive the money, Count?"
